thread.title: Mike Bobo says CSU football is its own enemy
thread.title_full: Mike Bobo says CSU football is its own enemy - The Denver Post

author: Mike Brohard
title: Mike Bobo says CSU football is its own enemy
text:
FORT COLLINS — The task at hand is obvious.
Boise State comes to Lubick Field at Hughes Stadium on Saturday night ranked 25th in the country and is the defending Mountain West champion.
The Broncos are 4-1, already own a win in conference play and are paced by — choose one or the other — an offense that has scored at least 52 points in each of its past three games or a defense with two shutouts in the past three weeks, allowing just 14 points in that stretch to Virginia.
Formidable, yes. But Colorado State coach Mike Bobo said the toughest test of all is much closer to home.
The Rams themselves.
"I think it's us," Bobo said, his team 2-3 overall, 0-1 in conference play entering the game. "We talked about it on Monday that we're our own worst enemy. We've got to handle ourselves. We've got to worry about the little things and correct what we can correct. We know Boise's good. We know they're good on offense. We know they're good on defense, good on special teams. We've got to become consistently good at all three phases, and that's what this week's been about, trying to get to that point."
Colorado State has yet to get there in any of the five games it has played. The Rams have won the turnover battle just once this season — against Texas-San Antonio — the one game in which they didn't turn over the ball. Boise State has feasted on teams making mistakes.
Advertisement But the mistakes go beyond that for Colorado State. CSU is among the most-penalized teams in the nation, in terms of flags thrown and yardage lost because of the infractions. Then there are the assignment busts on offense and defense.
Those on defense are often more obvious and have led to quarterbacks in the past two games running wild against the CSU defense. Last week, Utah State had eight explosive runs (gains of 15 yards or more) in a 33-18 victory, running for 298 yards in all.
"It's all about us," linebacker Kevin Davis said. "The couple of games we have lost have been little things or a couple of plays. If we eliminate those big plays, the big passes over the top and we play our runs and fits right, we'll have a good game."
The Rams, in spurts, have shown what is possible. They have held the lead in every game so far, but the issue has been being consistent with the play in all three phases, allowing three games to slip away from them, two resulting in overtime losses.
The running game that was so effective against Minnesota and Colorado was nonexistent last week, putting pressure on quarterback Nick Stevens. The fourth quarter against Utah State was one long passing down for the Rams, and the Aggies teed up the pass rush.
